newsitem.title: RUSSIA: Yeltsin sacks top foreign aide.
newsitem.headline: Yeltsin sacks top foreign aide.

text.p: Russian leader Boris Yeltsin relieved his long-term top foreign policy aide of his duties on Friday, the Kremlin said, without elaborating on what was behind the move.
"President Boris Yeltsin on Friday issued a decree relieving Dmitry Ryurikov of his duties in connection with his taking up other work," said a brief statement.
Such phrasing has been used in the past when an official is dismissed, but a Kremlin official declined to give further details.
Russian Public Television said Kremlin spokesman Sergei Yastrzhembsky would coordinate foreign policy in the presidential administration from now on.
The report did not make clear whether Yastrzhemsky, 42, would keep the job as spokesman he has held since Yeltsin's re-election in July.

Yastrzhembsky, who speaks several European languages and has brought a slick touch to the Kremlin, was previously ambassador to Slovakia and head of the Foreign Ministry's press and information department.
Ryurikov, 50, had been Yeltsin's foreign policy aide since the president's election in 1991 and was also made an extraordinary plenipontentiary in 1993.

He kept a low public profile but played a key behind-the-scenes role planning Yeltsin's negotiations over NATO expansion plans, arms control and other controversial post-Cold War issues as well as preparing for summit meetings.
